reviewText:
Imagine this for a game idea, take the deliberately paced action of the PlayStation classic Bushido Blade and put it into a beat-em-up in the vein of Final Fight. Add a little bit of point & click style puzzle solving and place it all in an alternate film-noir universe, where mobsters fight with katana instead of guns. In the hands of a great developer, this could've been an indie classic. Instead we ended up with samurai_jazz.

The game takes place over five acts, where you need to collect items and press switches to unlock more sections of the level until you eventually find the key item you need to progress to the next act, fighting any thugs along the way. Enemies die in one hit, but so do you, so combat places emphasis on blocking and countering. All of this sounds fine on paper, problem is, it completely fails in its execution.

The game is frustratingly difficult. Enemy placement is done in such a sloppy manner. There were many instances where you'll enter a room and be completely surrounded by enemies making for plenty of cheap deaths. What makes this worse is enemies respawn anytime you re-enter a room you just cleared, making levels where you're forced to backtrack a chore to play through. Even worse, there are puzzle rooms where you have to press switches in the correct order or else you die. So, if you make a wrong choice, you’ll have to start all over again, killing the same enemies, and hoping the next switch you press is the correct one. As if the frustratingly tedious gameplay weren't bad enough on its own, the game also suffers from unresponsive controls. There were way too many times I was moving right and when I tried moving left, my character would just stand there and I end up getting killed.

Even bad games are capable of immersing you in their story and setting if they’re interesting enough. Problem is, what little story that’s here is completely nonsensical. It starts with a guy committing seppuku before having you play as your character, who I assume is a detective. What exactly is the mystery here? The NPCs you interact with don't tell you anything other than get me [key item] and I'll let you pass". The ending doesn't explain anything either. The Jazz soundtrack is decent but the slow tempo doesn't fit with the action on screen at all. Plus the tracks are way too short and get annoying very quickly. Graphically speaking
date: the character sprites look decent enough
recommended: but the backgrounds all look very samey. This is especially bad in the fifth act of the game where it's very easy to get lost in
hoursPlayed: oh and did I mention enemies respawn every time you re-enter a room?\n\nSamurai_jazz is a game full of great ideas
voteText: and not a single one of them works. It fails to take advantage of its unique setting
helpfulPercent: the gameplay (when it works) is frustrating
votesTotal: it's just a bore to sit through. As another review already pointed out
votesFunny: this feels like a poorly made flash game straight out of Newgrounds. This game isn't worth the 99 cents and 2 hours I spent on it.\n\nIf I can end things on a slightly more positive note
commentsCount: developer Blaze Epic made a sequel/reimagining called Shin Samurai Jazz. The gameplay in that one actually looks a little more promising
column16: so that’s something to consider at least."

reviewText:
Stylish presentation, great music, good palette-choices, chilled atmosphere - terrible game. It's a sort of noirish action-adventure that would have trouble to impress people owning a famicom / NES back in '87.

samurai_jazz has this weirdly noir / chilled vibe about it, like reading a graphic novel at night in late summer - the meaning of it all escapes me, I got lost somehwere between [special cigarettes] and slashing samurai mobsters in half, maybe this game has a deeper meaning, a strong message about life and death or it is all a bunch of artsy baloney (my money is on the latter).

What I am pretty certain about is the fact that the actual game is a stiff, clunky mess. The controls are annoyingly unresponsive (on a 360 controller), the hitboxes seem to be nonsensical and almost random (clear advantage given to the enemies since their attacks seemingly have a wider arc that connects while you gotta align yourself with the enemies you want to hit) and there is very little feedback to your actions.

What's worse is the fact that enemies love to drop into background layers and attack you from there or you getting dropped into rooms with tons of enemies that storm you at once, with little space to navigate, making some rooms pretty tough unless you get lucky and clear a path before getting overwhelmed by unstoppable one-shot odds. Besides lots of combat against ever respawning enemies (if you leave a room, that is) you are doing inane fetch quests and asinine switch-puzzles (Act V was REALLY getting on my nerves towards the end). All for nothing though - there is never any sense of accomplishment, you are geting a few nonsensical lines of text at best or simply are able to venture forth into a new area or act.

Honestly, this game feels like a waste of time to me. The music is pretty chill and might be worth it, but the game is certainly not. Don't.

reviewText:
Only 1 sound track and 2 botton controls.
With only 9 megs of space it's probably the smallest game in my library, but it still manages to pack some fun into it.

PROS:
+ Noir/Samurai setting presented in 8 bit style.
+ Swordplay. Every enemy is hard to beat.
+ Hard retro feel. No handholding.
+ Fast to load and respawn.

CONS:
- Gamepad controls are set for the player to uncover. No settings whatsoever.
- Input lag. Slow to turn directions (vital for combat).
- Some enemies are just weird and do not fit with the setting.
- Anoying music. Only 1 awfull jazz" track.
- No saves
date: no passwords. All levels available to select from start.\n\nI can only recommend this if you enjoy taking retro styled game challenges
recommended: and you are ok with rage quiting games after a few minutes of gameplay. This is best played in short busts (maybe 1 scene per sitting)."

reviewText:
I've played Hard Mode through Act 1 (Out of 5) so far.

There are some some typos in game and the language (in the menu) that's basically all your first impression is pretty bad.
I assume that the harder you go, the more enemies you have and the less hp. So far It's challenging and dieing to 1-hit from the majority of enemies is quite self-explanatory.
The game has in my opinion no story at all, atleast it does not make sense why you have to go to several places. You get sent from A to B to C in order to pass through to the next Area at A.

Gameplay wise I really enjoy it. You are able to block an attack and attack yourself. Controls on a Joystick are obviously at disadvantage, although the game supports it pretty well. For my joystick the controls died rarely. I would suggest you either play it via D-Pad, because the controls for Keyboard are not that good.

You can move with either Arrow Keys or WASD, you block with Shift and Control, attack with Spacebar and Interact with Enter.. That's totally bad for playing with WASD and not the best setup for Arrow Keys, plus you can not customize the keys.
On the opposing side the game functions just good with a controller, and I'm presuming using XBOX controller: You move with as said D-Pad or Joystick, Interact with A and Attack with X or B.

I can see this game doing great at speedrunning, because it is mostly skillbased with some randomness involved (atleast in Hard Mode)

reviewText: WELL, after many infurating attempts I managed to beat the game. In terms of style I love it. The noir theme mix with samurai antics and jazz music in the background really sets the tone for a chill session of gaming...HOWEVER, this game is everything but chill and is pretty hard. Its all retro like so theres nothing to really tell you what to do execpt in the beginning, then comes the death after death after death after death battles where if you ♥♥♥♥ up, even when its not your fault, you die and have to start over in that scene again. Also since theres no saves if you rage quit (which trust me, you will rage quit it several times) you have to start all over from the beginning of an act. And after dying so many times on normal, which felt no different than hard, I put it on easy so I could just beat the game and even then it wasn't really easy. All in all this game was on sale for .24 cents when I got it and its .99 cents right now so even with its extreme amount of potential rage moments, I fell in love with the theme and would say its worth giving a short. Oh and if your looking for a story IDK what to tell you because I beat this game and still have no idea what the ♥♥♥♥ was going on

reviewText:
This game should be called samurai_muzak.

Let's start with the music. It gives the game a laid-back feeling, as if you were strolling through town after work on a slightly boring day. While killing some randos.
You're the Muzak Killer Ninja. (Or maybe not. You're some dude that wears a lot of brown stuff and a sword. I don't care.)
Unfortunately, each track starts to repeat after 15 seconds. Ok, potential wasted.

Now, for the setting. Streets, offices, shops, burger joints. A random, calm city. Together with the non-chalant music it DOES create something. Rando City is a an alright place. Not very big, though.

Well, gameplay. Slashing, killing pink things with long necks. And blue dudes. There seems to be no real system behind the combat. I don't know. It takes up 90% of the playtime, the rest is avoiding spikes on the ground, pressing buttons, primitive bridge troll quests and undercooked dialog.

It's all so half-baked and lukewarm. Maybe if the adventure sections" were a little more detailed
date: the music less repetitive and the "quirky dialog with the local inhabitants" (store blurb) more than a few lines about the next gateway item it could be something. But right now?\nSorry
recommended: no.\nI like the tone of the game
voteText: a little dull

reviewText: I had a lot of issues with this game. It came cheap, so that much is a plus. But I often found myself dying when I shouldn't have simply because the game didn't respond to my desired actions (such as not turning left when I wished to do so). While the fast pace of the game was nice, it felt very similar screen to screen. At times you had little time to even react before getting attacked. Leading to a die 10 times to get the timing just right" type of gameplay. There was also the fact that there seems to be an odd bug in the game. Where when you enter a new zone at times the enemies will "slide" to just outside of the map or to a section of the map they shouldn't be able to get to. Which makes dealing with them that much more difficult.\n\nPersonally
date: there is stuff I like about the game but it's mostly negative for me. I wanted to like this game

reviewText: 3.5/10\nBlaze Epic just can’t learn from his mistakes. This is an action adventure game. Once again, it nails the look and music of retro games. Where it falls apart, just like ninjahtic games, is gameplay. It repeats same mistakes. You mash attack at guys and 1 hit them, but like those games you die in 1 hit. So if you clear a room and last guy kills you have fun restarting it all. Also like ninjahtic mind tricks, every time you re-enter a room all guys respawn. Why does he think that’s a good idea? Having you move in 3d plane but having 2d looking levels are confusing. Guys can attack you at weird angles and you have a huge hitbox. In opposite you can only attack if standing directly in front of them and cant attack in directions, and they have tiny hitboxes to attack. You die all the time. Enemy placement is terrible. 1 room you start in you’re surrounded by 3 guys that just instant kill you. Computer blocks 2/3 attacks but game doesn’t explain how you block and never seems to work. Can’t jump. Lots of backtracking. Controller doesn't work in menus and there is no mouse cursor available. No real story. Just, no.

reviewText: I can't  help but feel disappointed in samurai_jazz. The game starts out strong with an 8-bit film noir meets samurai art style and jazzy soundtrack that work well together to create an atmospheric vibe few games manage to pull off. The game's tutorial" is comprised of a few of short messages graphitied on the walls and sides of buildings
date: and after learning the basic moveset I felt as though the combat system
recommended: which depends on proper positioning and timing
voteText: player mobility is poorly implemented in this game. Getting the player character into the right position and facing the right direction is no easy task
helpfulPercent: and since combat relys so heavily on player position and facing - you can only attack or block in the direction you are facing - the hampered mobility lead to a number of deaths that felt more like the game's fault than my own.\n\nTo add insult to injury
votesHelpful: not only are samurai_jazz's enemies more mobile than the player
votesTotal: easily able to flank the player when engaging with multiple enemies
votesFunny: but the game's enemy placement seems to be designed around the player's hampered movement. I lost count of the number of times I entered a room only to be immediately ambushed by 3 or more enemies moving in from different directions
commentsCount: often with my character facing away from all of them and open to attack. If I moved to block or attack one of them
column16: the other two would attack from the sides and kill me. More often than not
column17: the solution to one of these ambushes was to run around avoiding the enemies until I could get into a more favorable position.\n\nMany of the reviews here speak of the game's "challenge
column18:
but since the game's challenge depends on enemy placement and the player's hampered mobility, samurai_jazz feels less like a skill based game than a luck based one. The afforementioned entryway ambushes comprize most of the game's difficulty, but after they are taken care of, clearing out the remaining enemies in a room is fairly trivial as most of them attack one or two at a time, coming from the same direction, which makes them easy to block or kill.

The game's story is also lacking. The opening scene shows a samurai comitting harakiri (ritual suicide), after which the player character awakens from sleep. Given the film noir atmosphere, I expected to learn why this samurai decided to kill himself through the course of the game. Instead I was treated to a series of MacGuffin hunts straight out of a point and click adventure game, where I fetched cigarettes and bubble gum for strangers so they could let me pass through to the next alleyway. Why I wanted to get to the next allyway, I don't know. The game never bothers telling you why you're doing what you're doing.

The story" culminates in an ending that has me thinking that this entire game was a troll. The ending felt as though the developer was brandishing a middle finger squarly in the face of any players masochistic enough to make their way through to the end of samurai_jazz. After all those BS deaths
column19: hours spent wrestling with the controlls
column20: and having to fetch cigarettes for the umpteenth time
column21: the developers still manage to shout one last "FU" to the play at the very end. I won't spoil it for you
column22: but someone posted a video of it if you're interested and want to save yourself a few hours of playing a bad game."

reviewText: Urgh, this is a disaster. I *get* how the combat is supposed to work. But it feels like luck.  And most areas are just really enemy-spammy. I made it most of the way through Act 2 before realizing I was having zero fun with this mess and just giving up. Enemies can block at random, the controls are stiff, the game's not very well designed and not very compelling, just all-around bad.

reviewText: Even for a dollar, it's not worth it. The gameplay works in that the buttons do what they say. There's not really any skill involved just try to hit the other guy before he swings or get him caught on a piece of scenery so you can cheap him. Blocking, dashing, etc. are pointless because the AI just swings constantly until it hits you, so first attack wins 99% of the time. There's no challenge to any of the puzzles, it's just item fetch and push the obvious switch. The writing is bad, there's no story at all. Disappointing.

reviewText:
Samurai_jazz is a retro fighting game in which you progress through a storyline in a bustling city.

Pros:
+Cheap
+Simple controls/graphics

Cons:
-Hard to Control at times
-Glitchy Enemies
-Lack of content

Overall Rating:
4.5/10 Not-so-good game, However the idea was good.

reviewText:
So much frustration in such a short amount of time.
I don't mind the 8-bit graphics.
I don't even mind the one track of music.
I do mind the frustrating controls, bad enemy placement, and instakill traps.
BTW you encounter this just a few minutes into the game.
It's easy enough to figure out what to do which is good, but again, you will rage quit over the controls. I can almost guarantee it.

So no, I cannot recommend this unless you like frustration on a level that reminds me of getting a stinker of a game on the NES.

Nice effort but falls short in the key area. Control. Probably will be better than any games I ever make but still rage inducing enough for me to warn you away from it.

reviewText:
Reccommended, yes, great game, no.

Okay, first of all, I'm not the greatest gamer, so I played on easy, bite me. This game is quite enjoyable, actually, and it's defintely worth a couple of hours, especially for that money. Someone else bought this game for me, so it only made it better XD

Let's go a little in depth here, okay? It might get a little spoilery, but there is not really that much to spoil. In no particular order:

Art style: Lovely 8bit graphics. This could easily have been an NES classic. The characters look nice enough and you can distinguish the villians from the generic faceless NPC's. Most of the evildoers look like generic mobsters, minding their own business, until you come close and they draw their swords. Pretty cool.

Music: Repetative, but relaxing. The name of this game is Samurai_jazz, and it sure has a nice jazzy soundtrack. It's not something that will get on your nerves soon, mostly because you don't really have time to really listen to it.

Objective: This game consists of 5 stages (and a prologue and an end stage), and you pretty much do the same thing for the first four stages: retrieve some items and bring it to the two guys blocking the end. Pretty straightforward, nothing too difficult about that.

Enemies: This is where the game gets.. Weird.. As seen in the images above, there are the regular swordwielding mobsters, and some random fistfighters. Add to that a couple of firebreathing women with dragon like faces (I blame myself for not knowing this folklore >.>), giant red-colored clubwielders (common Japanese demons) and women with necks that stretch to the ceiling. The swords and clubs kill you instantly, so strike them before they strike you. The other opponents don't kill you instantly, but after a few hits, you're still dead. Somehow, the neckladies always managed to hit me before I hit them...

Gameplay: You walk into a room, filled with enemies, you die and then... you start back at the door. This game doesn't use lives or continues, and dying only resets the room. If you have pressed any buttons before dying, they are still pushed after revival, which helps. Your character can take a defensive stance and hop around to parry attacks, strike his sword and even climb small buildings. There are no power-ups, just your skills. You can play with either the arrow-keys or the WASD keys, which helps, I guess, but since you still have to use SHIFT, SPACEBAR and ENTER, you can't be too picky with where to place your hands.

Story: The game starts with a prologue. Here we see a samurai commit suicide, the Harakiri way. Then, the game starts... It took me a while to figure out that you were still part of that samurai, his Yin, trying to conquer his Yang side.

Boss: Stage 6 is the boss. You can swing your sword at him all you like, you won't be able to hit him by just slashing. Found that out after hitting him over 40 times :P He blocks all your attacks, so lunge at him! Be fast and he's as dead as can be. Yin has conquered Yang. And then Yang comes back and defeats Yin.... END... Did I miss something?

Well there you have it. It's fun, but don't play too long or you'll get frustrated. Even on easy, some rooms can be veeery tricky :D Have fun!

reviewText:
Samurai_Jazz is an action/adventure beat 'em up heavily inspired by NES games. Way more so than most retro games, in fact, down to the obtuse game design. The game pegs itself as a hack 'n slash noir, and I do love the idea of a noir samurai, but the story is entirely incomprehensible. I'm not meaning to say that it's convoluted, just that it's impossible to actually see. Your character makes vague references on occasion, and at the end of the game you fight an evil version of yourself. There's no direct statement as to what's going on or what you're doing, and it feels like a game poorly translated from another language. I supposed that adds to the retro, though.

The game design fairs a lot better than the narrative, setting up each room of enemies as a puzzle. Which enemy needs taken out first, what's the most efficient way to kill them all without getting cut down yourself? The game forces you to ask these questions the more you get into the game. This is only aided with the game's block mechanic, which allows you to strafe and parry at the cost of your movement speed. Combat requires immensely fast reflexes and an analytical mind. You will die, a lot.

The design also suffers from some noticeable setbacks, however, such as an inconsitent design for the most basic enemy: the samurai. They sometimes block your attacks, and sometimes don't. There's no rhyme or reason as to when they do block, and I've tried relentlessly to find an exploit. The only safe means to attack them appears to be parrying back and forth until they give in, but this isn't ideal when many of the rooms require you to destroy samurai quickly, lest you be destroyed by other enemies. It's also very easy to exploit the AI's field of vision, allowing you to lure out enemies one at a time, when they're meant to be faced as a group.

Even considering all of that, I think Samurai_Jazz is worth a look, especially considering its price. It nails the retro game feel far better than plenty of other games I've played. I definitely felt like I was sitting down and pouring my afternoon into an old, obtuse NES game, for better or worse.

reviewText:
Overall - 2.5/5 - BARELY A BARGAIN!
Samurai_jazz does indeed solve the mystery of where to get good value for your buck on Steam, but just barely. At $1.09 Steam gamers will be hard-pressed to find such a large, reasonably challenging game at such a low price, despite the lack of Steam features. If gamers want a visually-appealing, at times sickeningly action-packed puzzle game look no further; you might want to give Shin Samurai Jazz a look as well.

Read the full review for this game and others at Budget Gaming Review!
http://www.budgetgamingreview.com/2015/07/samuraijazz.html

reviewText:
This game has a lot of charming elements to it. I really do like the relaxed soundtrack, the graphics and artwork, and most of the mechanics. Controls work perfectly, but that goes without saying.

So both the audio and visual departments are an 8/10, I did feel like all parts of the city could have used a unique tileset, or possibly a palette swap here and there between chapters. This is not even that prominent, so it doesn't really matter. As with sound, no complaints with the ost, but the sfx get burned into your ears the longer you play. But, that isn't even prominent either.

For the mechanics, I would say a borderline 5/10. This is only because of the combat system. The enemies and everything are separated and varied, but the enemy placement is freakin infuriating. I enter a building and need to hold block right away, and after 15 attempts, I eventually strike lucky and don't get killed right away. This, would be easily fixable, too.

But that sums it up. I would basically give the overall game a 7/10, fun for 3 hour intervals, and I still pick it up and play here and there. Replay value is something that Samurai Jazz has going for it.

reviewText: The direction controls for combat on this are frustrating; they leave you vulnerable and often facing away from your target. The jump and climb mechanic isn't very fluid and requires you to spend a second up against the location before it can trigger. The missions follow a pattern of get a MacGuffin needed to get access to the other MacGuffin you needed to get past the level. I lost interest after about 20 minutes.
